body: Note: I will rebase and squash these commits before merging, since I suspect there will be a load of changes before this is ready anyhow.

Sorry for the many styling error commits.
I can't get the `make check` running locally.

EDIT:
Done:
- When the actor dies, the beam should stop emitting if still busy.
- When the actor is ordered to stop, the beam should stop emitting if still busy.

Tested:
- That walls properly block the beam if the beam is not set to be 'High'.
- That the projectile properly works for 'short' beams, such as D2K sonic ball.
- That the projectile properly works for brief instant-hit beams, such as TS railguns.

Need Advice:
For the TODO:
"The target is a static position, so if you fire at a moving actor, even while the firing actor is still busy emitting the beam, the head does not 'track' the target. Not sure how to do this. (Would like to make this an Info setting.)"

I was thinking of making a GuidedLineImpactProjectile, which does not have an inaccuracy attribute, but rather can be set to have its target track the targeted actor (if an actor is targeted), either while its tail is still emitting, or while the projectile is alive at all (i.e. tail has already left the source's barrel.)

Would this make sense? Or should I rather just have a "Guided" attribute on the current projectile, which overwrites the inaccuracy if any?

I've implemented a basic raycasting check for actors between two points, for a given beam width.
I'll fix Travis errors and squash this tomorrow to make reviewing easier. Calling it a night for now.

I've run some tests in TS with disruptors (sonic beam) and ghost stalker (railgun), and the raycasting appears to be working well for various beam widths.

@anyone I know the commits aren't squashed and quite ugly atm, but I would appreciate a quick review of the raycast in world util if possible.
Test pan out so far, but just want to know if I am making any obvious errors (haven't worked on OpenRA in over a year, so I am very much out of sync with changes to the engine.)

I'm having trouble with the raycasting mathematics.
Currently only intersecting actors close to either the head or the tail, but not inbetween.
Busy looking into it.

EDIT: I've given up trying to use only full integers.
Resorting to using doubles (floating points) has solved the raycasting problems.
I'm not sure how to do this in a purely full integer fashion.

I don't understand the code well enough to review it properly, but I intend to give this some in-game testing this weekend.

Could you rebase in the mean time?

At a high level the logic in `FindActorsInRaycast` looks good.  At a medium level I have pointed out a couple of major flaws that will need to be fixed before we review this further.  At a low level, there are a few style issues that i'm deliberately ignoring (commenting them all now just creates a bunch of noise while there are more important things to fix).  This will be a useful method that will also fix our long-standing projectile-wall bug.

Great start! :smile:

@pchote: I've changed the code to use integer only calculations.

I realize now that .LengthSquared takes the z-axis into account, so (as an interim hack) I take the projected point (along the ray length) as having a Z value equal to the average of the source and target Z values.
I unfortunately do not know how to adjust the math to calculate the actual Z of the projected point.
This means it **will fail** for raycasts between source and target that has large difference in Z offset.

Also, I've not had time to try doing the suggested t = 0 -> t = 1024. I will try that next.
But I figured that the current version works for integer only math, so it is worth as an intermediate commit.

TODO: I still have to incorporate the PR of @reaperrr for the overselection based on largest health radius. (#9174)
TODO: Incorporate use of `var projection = WPos.Lerp(source, target, t, 1024);`, simplifying
`var newX = (int)((double)target.X + t * (double)(source.X - target.X));`
`var newY = (int)((double)target.Y + t * (double)(source.Y - target.Y));`
`var projection = new WPos(newX, newY, 0);`
There is a `.HorizontalLengthSquared` property for calculating only the x and y components.

Converting double → int without scaling by an extra factor (which is where the suggested 1024 comes in) isn't going to work very well because of the differences between integer and floating point division.  [number] / [larger number] will always return 0.

> There is a .HorizontalLengthSquared property for calculating only the x and y components.

Excellent, that will help a lot.

> [number] / [larger number] will always return 0.

Yes, I had that issue in the first round of trying integer only. (The effect is rather obvious in game, as only actors close to the 'head' and 'tail' of the ray are intersected. None along the ray length are intersected.) I've managed to avoid that this round.

I've currently done the following:
`// Should be dist = (target - source).LengthSquared;`
`// But in order to avoid floating points, we do not divide here, but rather work with the large numbers as far as possible.`
`var dist = 1;`
`var ans = (xDiff + yDiff) / dist;`

And then only divide here, after first multiplying:
`// Using floating points, this would be: var newX = (int)((double)target.X + t * (double)(source.X - target.X));`
`// where t would already be divided by squaredLength.`
`var newX = (int)(target.X + (t * (source.X - target.X) / squaredLength));`
`var newY = (int)(target.Y + (t * (source.Y - target.Y) / squaredLength));`

I used `Log.Write` to log the steps of the calculation along the way, and it was returning values close to what the floating point math had returned.

I'll implement the \* 1024 factor and do the same, and see if the accuracy improves.

~~The projectile isn't blocked properly either. This can be easily tested in d2k.~~
Got excited and made a mistake reading the yaml. Blocking appears to work O.K.

It seems that the rendering for the projectile has a forced three-d look. It looks a little bit odd when changing from 270 degrees to 285 or so. This should probably be fixed later, though.
Also, I noticed weird stuff happens when the projectile hits a wall. It doesn't even render at all some times.
It seems to work fine aside from a couple of issues. It doesn't seem to kill perf either.

@Everyone: I'm busy addressing the comments. Might only be ready in a day or two as I want to spend a bit of time getting proper handling of "projectile blocked by actor" in, it was mainly just a proof of concept approach, and needs a lot of TLC.

@pchote:
With regards to:

> Don't forget about WPos.Lerp

I need some help on this.
To standardize t = 0 -> t = squaredLength to t = 0 -> t = 1024 I will have to multiply numerator and then divide by a denominator (if I want to work with purely whole numbers).
I am at a loss as to how to calculate these values without using floating points.

Can I not rather just use var projection = WPos.Lerp(source, target, (int)t, (int)squaredLength); ? Since the length of the line is squaredLength, and t is the length along that line at which point we want the new projected position?

I've resorted to just calculating the correct Z position using `t` in the meantime.

@Everyone:
I've split out the function that returns the position along the line for the closest point to the target, mainly so that I can now call it when the beam is being 'blocked' by an actor. During TS tests you should notice the beams no longer 'jump about' when colliding with walls.

I've also left in the `Explosion: small_bang` in the weapon yaml, just so while testing occurs it is obvious which actors are hit by the beams.
Like I mentioned above t = 0 → squaredLength (or even better 0 → length) is fine.  The key point was that 0 → 1 wouldn't work.

@pchote: Apologies, then. I had misunderstood.
I have attempted to simplify the three lines in question using `WPos.Lerp`, but as the function does not support longs and a simple `(int)` conversion does not work (failed during testing), I've left lines 139 -> 142 as using the math calculation.

I believe all the comments up to this point has been addressed now.
~~Once this has a tentative +1 I'll remove the `Explosion: small_bang` from the weapon definitions.~~ Already done. I feel confident enough in the collision code to no longer need the visual cue.

Note: I do not have access to change labels on issues, so I cannot remove the Changes requested label to reflect the above.
Rebased.
@penev92 Thanks for removing the label.

Read through the code and tested in game. Seems good to me.
The TS disruptor behaves weirdly though (ordering it to move away or attack another target while it's still firing will not make it stop firing and will make it fire zero length beams afterwards), but I suppose this should be a part of another PR that takes care of properly notifying the line impact projectile that the attack was canceled. And of course the beam renderable could look nicer, but that's already a TODO, so...
Note: I missed the new comment on the of WPos.Lerp. Busy with that now.

@pchote: Thanks for the help with WPos.Lerp. I've added in the code you provided. Works well.
I have upped the width and lowered the alpha as requested.

Sidenote: Given how the beam is rendered, the beamwidth doesn't work well for all directions.
I can attempt to address this in a follow-up PR, but as it is right now it just doesn't look pretty.
@pchote: I've fixed the monument to my ignorance. Translucency should be fixed now.
Something is wrong with the rendering (or the yaml settings) of the sonic beam in TS, it's like 3 cells(!) wide.
@reaperrr I'll take another look, seemed fine during the last playtest.

![widebeam](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2857877/10641161/5493c3dc-7818-11e5-81c2-03daec92583d.png)

This is how it looks like for me (I ran make all again to be sure).

@reaperrr Allright, the only thing I could spot is this
(in LineImpactProjectile.cs)

```
yield return new BeamRenderable(headPos, 0, tailPos - headPos, info.BeamRenderWidth, color);
```

where `info.BeamRenderWidth` is an `int` but the `BeamRenderable` takes a `float` for width.

Could you try to change the line to

```
yield return new BeamRenderable(headPos, 0, tailPos - headPos, (float)info.BeamRenderWidth, color);
```

Adding the float cast, and see if that makes any difference?
(Tried it on my side, still renders the same for me even if I do that. But I'm thinking that perhaps the implicit casts to float might differ across systems?.)
